A **dwarvish cloak** is a type of [cloak](/wiki/Cloak "Cloak") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is made of [cloth](/wiki/Cloth "Cloth"), and appears as a **hooded cloak** when [unidentified](/wiki/Identification "Identification").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Description](#Description)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Variants](#Variants)

  - [5.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [5.2 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [5.3 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [5.4 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [5.5 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [6 References](#References)

## Generation

[Dwarven](/wiki/Dwarf_\(starting_race\) "Dwarf (starting race)") characters start the game with knowledge of the dwarvish cloak.

In addition to random generation, armor [shops](/wiki/Shop "Shop") and general stores can stock dwarvish cloaks.

Hobbits have a 1⁄10 chance of [being generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") a dwarvish cloak.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) Live [dwarves](/wiki/Dwarf_\(monster_attribute\) "Dwarf (monster attribute)") have a 6⁄7 chance of being generated with a dwarvish cloak.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

## Description

While worn, a dwarvish cloak provides no base [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") and [MC1](/wiki/MC1 "MC1"). Selling or buying a dwarvish cloak will [auto-identify](/wiki/Auto-identify "Auto-identify") it.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Per [commit b98a70e3](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/b98a70e3ecaa4cbb5eb18c99de61cf84a2b52213), dwarvish cloaks protect against inventory damage from fire and cold 9⁄10 of the time.

## Strategy

While almost any cloak is better than a dwarvish cloak (minus the similar [orcish cloak](/wiki/Orcish_cloak "Orcish cloak")), the dwarvish cloak is still enough to protect armor underneath from damage, and the [scroll of destroy armor](/wiki/Scroll_of_destroy_armor "Scroll of destroy armor") and the [destroy armor](/wiki/Destroy_armor_\(monster_spell\) "Destroy armor (monster spell)") [monster spell](/wiki/Monster_spell "Monster spell") will always target the outermost layer of armor first. If you test unknown [scrolls](/wiki/Scroll "Scroll") by reading them, a dwarvish cloak can be useful as a throwaway cloak to catch destroy armor, after which you can put your regular cloak back on.

Collecting and selling dwarvish cloaks provide some easy money early in the game: most characters are likely to run across dozens of these cloaks while exploring the [Gnomish Mines](/wiki/Gnomish_Mines "Gnomish Mines") and fighting off [dwarves](/wiki/Dwarf_\(monster_attribute\) "Dwarf (monster attribute)"), and lawful characters can collect them from peaceful dwarves killed by their pet (or by their own hand if they are willing to risk alignment record penalties). The sample [autopickup exception](/wiki/Autopickup_exception "Autopickup exception") below is set so that it will turn itself off automatically after you cash in:

```
# #raise cash for speed runners, on the way down to mine town
AUTOPICKUP_EXCEPTION="<*hooded cloak"
```

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

The inventory protection from dwarvish cloaks makes them much more valuable assets in the early game, and they can compete for the cloak slot: a character can swap between the dwarvish cloak and a different cloak depending on their needs, while selling spare cloaks as normal, until they find a viable [bag](/wiki/Bag "Bag") to carry vulnerable items in and/or other forms of inventory protection (e.g. extrinsic [cold](/wiki/Cold_resistance "Cold resistance") and [fire resistance](/wiki/Fire_resistance "Fire resistance")).

## History

The dwarvish cloak first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0"). From this version to [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"), including some variants based on these versions, the dwarvish cloak grants [MC2](/wiki/Magic_cancellation_\(3.4.3\) "Magic cancellation (3.4.3)") while worn.

## Variants

Some variants may give dwarves an AC bonus for wearing a dwarvish cloak, including dwarven characters.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), the dwarvish cloak grants MC2 when worn.

[Upgrading](/wiki/Upgrading "Upgrading") a dwarvish cloak will produce either an [oilskin cloak](/wiki/Oilskin_cloak "Oilskin cloak") or an [elven cloak](/wiki/Elven_cloak "Elven cloak").

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), the dwarvish cloak grants a +1 AC bonus to dwarves that wear them, including dwarven characters.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), a dwarvish cloak grants 0 AC, 1 [DR](/wiki/DR "DR") and MC2 while worn. Dwarven [Nobles](/wiki/Noble "Noble") start each game with a +1 dwarvish cloak, while dwarven [Binders](/wiki/Binder "Binder") start each game with a +0 [burnt](/wiki/Burnt "Burnt") dwarvish cloak.

Live dwarves and wizard driver [Amm Kamerel](/wiki/Amm_Kamerel "Amm Kamerel") may generate with dwarvish cloaks.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), the dwarvish cloak grants a +1 AC bonus to dwarves that wear them, including dwarven characters.

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), the dwarvish cloak grants a +1 AC bonus to dwarves that wear them, including dwarven characters.

Upgrading an orcish cloak will produce a dwarvish cloak, and upgrading a dwarvish cloak will produce an elven cloak.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 363](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L363)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 369](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L369)
